steps.description: Te precursor solution was prepared by heating a mixture of 0.96 g of Te in 6 mL TBP (or 10 mL TOP) under microwave field for about 90 s at 220 °C under constant stirring, and then left to cool down.
For the Bi (or Sb) precursor, 1.6 g of BiCl3 was dissolved in 20 mL ethylene glycol. The stoichiometry of ternary compositions can be tuned by replacing BiCl3 with equivalent moles of SbCl3.

A 1-mL aliquot of thioglycolic acid (TGA) was added to the dissolved precursors, and then sonicated to obtain a homogeneous solution. The two prepared solutions (Te-TOP complex and Bi/Sb - EG) were mixed.

The mixed solution was added to a 100 mL Teflon vessel and run in the MW reactor for 2 min dwell time at 220 °C under constant stirring. The product (dark powder), about 2 g per vessel, was then cooled down to room temperature.
The as-prepared Bi2−xSbxTe3 phases were separated clearly from the solvent (EG) by centrifuging and washing with iso-propanol and acetone several times.

The powders were consolidated using Spark Plasma Sintering (SPS) with 15 mm inner diameter graphite cylinders and top/bottom punches. The SPS temperature was set to 400 °C with a heating rate of 30 °C/min and 1-min dwell time. 50 MPa pressure was applied gradually during the SPS process, with a holding time of 1 min for both current and pressure. Finally, the pellet was cooled from 400 °C to 250 °C, while the load was decreased from 50 MPa to 0 MPa. The pellets were then removed and polished in three steps to remove contaminated surfaces and obtain a smooth surface with 1 µm roughness.

equipment.name: X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRPD)
equipment.settings: X’Pert PRO, Cu–Kα1 radiation, 0.24° step size, 0.04°/s scan speed

equipment.name: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS)
equipment.settings: 426 system configuration, SCIENTA R3000 hemispherical photoelectron spectrometer, monochromatic Al Kα source at 450 W

synthesis.notes: This microwave-assisted polyol synthesis method is truly scalable, energy and cost-effective, and reproducible, yielding high purity nanostructured Bi2−xSbxTe3 (x: 0–2) materials in a very rapid manner (2 min) and high yield (>8 g/batch). The resultant materials exhibit high crystallinity, phase purity, and platelet morphology. The surface chemistry showed a mixture of metallic and oxide phases, and zeta-potential analysis exhibited a systematic change of isoelectric point with composition. As-made materials were directly sintered into pellets using SPS. The method paves the way for large-scale production and implementation towards large-area thermoelectric (TE) applications, including the potential for fabricating hybrid thermoelectric films and complete TE devices by combining n-type and p-type materials. The process involves the reduction of Bi3+/Sb3+ ions by ethylene glycol, which then catalyzes the bond breaking between Te and TOP to form the crystalline Bi2−xSbxTe3 phase.
